snippet: In the five weeks since Egypt’s military ousted the Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, the endemic violence here has spiraled into something like an insurgency.
abstract: Northern Sinai Peninsula, long a relatively lawless zone, has become a dark harbinger of risks elsewhere in Egypt if interim government cannot peacefully resolve its standoff with Islamist protesters camped out in Cairo; endemic violence in region has spiraled into something like an insurgency, with mysterious gunmen attacking military and police facilities nightly.

byline.contributor: Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting from Cairo, and Muhammad Sabry from El Arish, Egypt.

lead_paragraph: In the five weeks since Egypt’s military ousted the Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, the endemic violence here has spiraled into something like an insurgency.

headline.main: Lawless Sinai Shows Risks Rising in Fractured Egypt
headline.print_headline: Lawless Sinai Shows Risks Rising in Fractured Egypt

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
